Once, I went to a very distant place far from any city. There is no noise of cars, no sounds of nature or even water running. It’s an old mine, forgotten by everyone centuries ago. It is one of the scariest and yet most loved places for me. When you just stand there, looking deep into the weak supports, broken wooden corrupted rails, feel this deep void, sense this place, your problems appear so… easy… predictable, controllable in some way.
This mine collapsed 1,5 years ago, and it almost made me cry.
Why? Because it reminds me about anyones worst friend and enemy, time.
AI? Medicine? Physics? All for making more time. While people run for money and joy, I storm my mind to find a way to buy just a millennia of time, learning so much information, searching all the peaks, to find nothing…
Sometimes I wonder if there was something in that mine that could help me to solve just even one of major problems in any of the ways I found,
but again, I remember that incredibly loud silence and understand that it was the answer. Silence.
I cannot buy time for myself for millennia. Not at any cost of time and work. And even if I do, it would not be “me” anymore. It’s completely different person, with memory of “me” in his past, and all of his iterations in past time…
That’s why I hate philosophy. It truly likes to answer in form of silence.

There are several really huge logical inconsistencies in this video. And several claims about a certainty of "something" that we actually have no empirical knowledge about, i.e. we simply dont know. But even if that possibility was actually true, the logical inconsistencies i mentioned first would not follow from that, while they are logically inconsistent in on themselves.

First of, this video and thinking in it presents the usual two simplified binary opposite extremes as if those are actually true and encompass everything, even things we do not know, we only have to decide which one is better. Which is completely wrong and logically untenable. Even if we assume that religious/spiritual idea is simply wrong, we cannot claim some other things are true that we have no evidence for. That's directly opposite to scientific method and science in general.

Second, the notion that we are somehow, one way or another eternal or that "there is always another day" and the fact we avoid thinking about our personal deaths - IS actually caused by evolution and our biology. It has an evolutionary advantage and a utility. Yes it also has downsides, but that shouldn't be taken as anything special since almost everything evolution created has downsides and faults. Evolution is not a perfection making machine. So, nothing substantial can be concluded based only on the fact that these types of thinking and behavior have their downsides. They do, and they also have positive sides. Evolution is messy. Imperfect. Life and living beings are therefore the same. As we can all witness every single day.

Third, people don't really have this delusion of permanence. We are all aware of our deaths - and that's exactly why we push that understanding away, because it is debilitating, paralyzing, destructive. If we were to actually poll people globally, i would bet that we would find very, very few individuals who never - ever - had a moment of realization of their own impending death.
We do behave like we think we are permanent, and avoid talking or thinking about personal deaths - but that's not what we really - really believe. Not even the religious who will do everything, including physical violence to convince others that they are completely convinced in the everlasting permanence - because when they manage to convince others that personal conviction becomes stronger.

Yet, we don't know either way. Scientifically we know such permanence cannot happen in specific ways - but not absolutely.
I'm not talking simply about some undiscovered physical properties, but rather that our understanding of time may not be correct. And there is really a lot we don't yet know in many ways.

Then there is your notion of "nothingness", which is a purely human construct. We invented the idea about it based on our own macro universe everyday simple demands and necessities. It has nothing to do with the actual physical universe in which real "nothing" as we imagine it - does not exist. There is no "nothing" in this Universe, everything is something. And we also have no idea what was "before" the big bang". We actually do not know there was a "nothing" before "it". We assume, but we do not know.

(Trained-as-a-physicist here.) The faith that Veritasium puts in 21st century science is disturbingly blinkered. Science has not yet begun to approach the biggest questions: What is consciousness? What defines "now"? (The equations of physics certainly don't.) Why, after a century, do we still not have a consensus on what quantum mechanics is telling us about the nature of reality? (Last I checked, there were at least 6 competing "interpretations" of QM.) Why are our two most successful theories, general relativity and quantum mechanics, so hard to reconcile? (The chances that string theory is correct seem extremely small, after 35 years of research with no predictions.) And perhaps the toughest one: why is there anything at all? Or, in the context of the video, why, if at one point there was truly nothing - no mathematics, physics, space, time, anything at all - how can there now be something?
So writing off the idea that the seat of our consciousness might be eternal smacks of the same kind of myopic thinking (that science has almost all the answers) that stymied physics towards the end of the 19th century. People at that time thought that, apart from one or two remaining puzzles, we had nailed the big picture. This was before special and general relativity, and before quantum mechanics. We didn't have the big picture at all.
I was a physicist for 12 years, a systems engineer and machine learning researcher for 30, and now I'm a musician. I love science, but I also believe that it is highly likely that the most important part of us is truly eternal. This belief has not limited my ambitions at all, in contrast to the claims made by the video. I have no problem with atheism - I concede that my beliefs could be wrong. But please don't project your imagined limitations on the rest of us.

The idea that we would be cowardly in immortality and forever guilty of our mistakes doesn't make any sense. Immortality would give us the confidence to fail and stand up again and learn and rise over and over to forever grow and develop ourselves. No wonder our fictional superheroes are immortal or effectively immortal. Fear of failure can only come if you think that failure will have lasting consequences for as long as you exist, and as long as you care about the consequences. Do you care about the consequences? If you think that there is value in nihilism, then why do you care about the consequences? You chose to have a family, to experience the world, to experience beauty, to be a good citizen, to respect law and order, and essentially to live a meaningful and productive life discovering the world. So, it is logically impossible that the idea that we can accept the emptiness and meaninglessness of a future looming in the horizon, can live hand-in-hand with the idea of living a life as if it had meaning. You cannot produce meaning in the present knowing and believing that the future has no meaning. It is not possible. And you cannot transfer meaning to another being to effectively turn your existence immortal after you are gone, if you believe that ultimately every life will reduce to dust and every bit of individuality and consciousness will disintegrate into nothingness. If the whole universe has no beginning, no end, no goal, no purpose, no meaning, then nothing at any point in space or time has meaning, and as such, you cannot claim to embrace nihilism when you don't in fact live your life as a true nihilist. You are still living with meaning. So, where is the delusion? Is the delusion to fool ourselves into forgetting about the nothingness and meaninglessness to come? Is the delusion the conscious acceptance of a transient meaning, while ignoring the inevitable logical conclusion that there can be no meaning for the individual in the present without somehow the individual being eternal? Or is the delusion the very idea that consciousness or individuality doesn't carry over, and that existence ultimately has no meaning? It is self-evident that people thrive by living as if they matter and as if their existence and their experiences have meaning and purpose. You can argue that this is just how we happen to be programmed, by mere chance, and that ultimately this is also a delusion. But one cannot seriously claim to believe that, while living a life with goals, aspirations, motivations, ambitions and desires. There is no other possible outcome for the nihilist than to be a fool. He's a fool to call himself one while not truly being one, and he's a fool to be the true one who does the only thing that a true nihilist does which is to end his own existence, because he then believes the ideas created in his own delusional mind. So, to me nihilism doesn't offer any solution, but only new philosophical problems which are frankly not that hard to solve. Nihilism sabotages our quest for truth and our thirst for life. Look, the logic is simple. The only intelligent way to live life is to live as if life continues somehow after death, for the simple reason that we only have something to lose if that turns out to be true, and we turned out to have lived a misguided life that was counter-productive to our existence in the future. If it turns out that in death we disappear and cease to exist as individual or consciousness, then how we lived won't make any difference to you or to anybody. Luckily, we seem hard-wired to pursue a life productively and with meaning, so the job of living as if there is life after death is not that difficult. Maybe it's not by chance that we are wired that way.

This video disagrees with itself in so many ways. The video is filled with a "tone" to suggest that life has meaning and is beautiful, yet his words suggest quite the opposite.

We have to be very careful with nihilism. If we as a species would come to embrace nihilism; think about what that would mean. It means there is no reason to protect life. Someone who is suffering has zero reason to fight through it and should rather just kill themselves. In fact, all those African children dying of hunger; we should just kill them all to put them out of their misery. The more we apply the "theory" and act accordingly with it in our daily lives, the more horrifying the world becomes. The simple truth is that the reason that a nihilist today can feel fulfilled is that time has engrained him with the values of the society he is surrounded by. A society that has been formed, molded, by beliefs such as Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism; all beliefs that include eternity and an afterlife. Now, is there an afterlife and are these beliefs accurate? That is another topic. However, if there ISN'T an afterlife, life has zero meaning. There really is no debate to this. It doesn't matter whether you live life in fear or in fulfilment, because once you die, you'll never remember it. Fear, failure, success, love, loneliness, murder, theft, drugs. They are all of equal outcome. If you find fulfilment in suicide bombing a skyscraper, go right ahead. That's why this video just seems so contradictory to me, and irrational.

Now, before you go jump off a cliff, I want to share something which to me is quite interesting. My dad was an agnostic, who had a very "Hume'esque" way of thinking bordering on nihilism. He was also a very rational person, and smart enough to study physics in MIT, to later become an economist (he's worked in the IMF, World Bank, Ministry of economics of Nicaragua, and the HKMA in Hong Kong). The thing is, at one point in his life (aged 21, I believe), he reached rock bottom. He felt life had no meaning, he was a social recluse, and so he decided to pray. Quite simply, he prayed to God "I give up, I don't know what's true, I need help". He decided soon afterwards to visit a seminary near Hamburg, Germany (where he lived at the time) and met with one of the seminarists for advice. The man told him something along the line of "don't think so much about yourself, try to think of others". My dad didn't really feel much different right afterwards, and the words were kinda empty. Soon afterwards, however, and he hadn't even had a chance to put the seminarists words into practice, he says he felt a sudden "feeling" (he doesn't use the word feeling, because it was more akin to "knowledge") out of nowhere that he describes as an immense paternal love for him from someone very real. A love so powerful and real that he says he was more sure of its existence than his own existence. He is now 74, and has been a devout Catholic since that moment. Far from feeling "afraid of failure", as Veritasium mentions, he felt an immense peace which, though it didn't last forever, gave him a hope, an assurance, that life doesn't end here, that it has meaning. He is one of the most serene and peaceful individuals I know.

I have not yet had that same experience and not every good Christian does, but damn, does it give you something to think about. Veritasium is very right that a belief like Christianity can cause someone to be afraid and fear failure, but only because its true message has been distorted, and because people don't have that direct relationship with God, which is what Christianity is all about. It isn't about doing this or not doing that, it's about loving God and Him loving you. Once that relationship is established, then doing the right thing isn't a chore, it's a blessing. Unfortunately, many Christians have twisted the meaning to be opposite: follow laws, so that then you can know God, when in fact, it should be "know God, so that you can follow (and love) the law (which is simply natural law; that which if we follow, we'll be happier; it isn't even a strictly religious term).

Mind you, we SHOULD live like every day is our last, because eternity isn't simply an addition of time, it is an echo of what we do now. The concept of hell isn't something to make you fear failure, quite the opposite, it should drive you to act, but in peace, with the knowledge that God will guide you. Ultimately, hell is our choice of abandoning that which makes us happy. There really is no greater hell than choosing to believe life has no meaning, and living according to that. The knowledge of hell is actually a blessing. A call to act. Which doesn't mean we should despair if we don't act this once. Strive ever to get better, but never despair. God will eventually get you out. Above all, hope. That is my message to anyone who sees this and feels empty.

I respect your opinion and your right to believe whatever you want, but for me it is the total opposite. The ideas of nihilism make me feel like life isn't worth living, as least not in any good way. I mean, what is the point of spending your whole life trying to build relationships with people and create a legacy if they are all going to die anyway and no one will ever remember you? If mankind is a meaningless speck in the cosmos than anything I could ever in this life would be pathetic by comparison to everything else in the universe. Even if I single handedly ended world hunger and poverty overnight, what does it matter? All those people whose lives I changed are all going to die within a century and forget about all of it, the good and the bad. And the universe as a whole would not even notice. It makes me feel like the only way to live is to lie, cheat, steal, kill, sleep around, and get high as much as possible before I die, because work sucks, and when I die it is all over, so why not do whatever the heck I feel like doing in the moment and enjoy my brief blip amidst eternity?
On the other hand, thinking that mankind might be eternal gives meaning to my life is dozens of ways. It means that any little kindness I show anyone will be forever etched into that mind and heart that I touched and will endure throughout eternity. It also means that any bad thing I do will theoretically be remembered forever, so it motivates me to be good rather than evil. It also means that any relationships I build here will have a chance to exist afterwards, and that gives even more meaning to interactions with friends and family. And while people may die and leave mortality, if our consciousness continues on, then anything I learn and experience in this life will carry one with me, so it motivates me to learn more, become better, to learn how to be happier, more productive, and contribute more, and never stop progressing. This also means that my potential is beyond the current comprehension of humanity. Think about it. How much can a person learn and grow in 100 years? Now imagine if that person had a 100,000,000 years instead. How much would they grow and learn then? Would anything be beyond their ability? Wouldn't they be able to learn enough about science and build enough capital to single handedly create and run an entire galaxy all by themselves?
As for failures, people are going to remember your failures whether there is life after death or not. They will remember it during the whole of mortality, so the only way to escape your failures is to kill the people that remember them, or else kill yourself so you don't have to deal with it. That isn't very liberating in my opinion.
However, believing in a God who can forgive sins is liberating. It means that even if you did screw up those mistakes can be wiped away, whether here or in the hereafter, and so you can actually let go of your troubled past and live in peace and tranquility, only focusing on the present, the future, and the good moments of the past.
But that isn't all. Believing in an afterlife also means that I don't have to rush around life like a chicken with my head cut off trying to do, be, and experience everything before my turn is over. It means that I can live life at a relaxed pace knowing that if there is something that I didn't get to do here I will have an eternity to do it later. It also means that I don't have to fear death because death is merely a transition from one phase of life to a other. Like going from high to college.
Believing in a God expands that even more though. Believing in an all-powerful, all-knowing, all-loving God means that anything that is bad or unpleasant about my life can and will be fixed at some loony in the future. If I am ugly now, and God loves me, he will want me to be handsome so I can be happier. This means that at some point in eternity he will change me from ugly to handsome. Likewise if I am crippled, or socially awkward or bad a sports, or cowardly, or cruel, or undisciplined, then at some point in the future all of those problems will be fixed. But is also works for external problems too, like being poor, or suffering from a terrible illness, or being denied opportunities, or suffering pain and discomfort. A just and merciful and loving God would not allow that to go on forever. Eventually he would stop it and reverse it, compensating us for all of the bad things we experienced in life, or for all of the good things that we DIDN'T get to experience in life. In other words, God can't stop people from hurting others, because that would impinge oontheir free will and so would be unjust, so he has to let us suffer. In narratives about the problem of climate change, loss features dramatically and terrifyingly but is located in the future or in places remote from [us]. Norgaard finds that for the highly educated and politically savvy residents [...], global warming was both common knowledge and unimaginable.

And we don’t have to do anything to bring about this future.

All we have to do is nothing.

"Your life's journey has an outer purpose and an inner purpose. The outer purpose is to arrive at your goal or destination, to accomplish what you set out to to, to achieve this or that, which, of course, implies future. But if your destination, or the steps you are going to take in the future, take up so much of your attention that they become more important to you than the step you are taking now, then you completely miss the journey's inner purpose, which has nothing to do with /where/ you are going or /what/ you are doing, but everything to do with /how/. It has nothing to do with future but everything to do with the quality of your consciousness at this moment. ... After that [realizing your inner purpose], the outer purpose is just a game that you may continue to play simply because you enjoy it. It is also possible to fail completely in your outer purpose and at the same time totally succeed in your inner purpose. Or the other way around, which is actually more common: outer riches and inner poverty, or to "gain the world and lose your soul," as Jesus puts it. Ultimately, of course, /every/ outer purpose is doomed to "fail" sooner or later, simply because it is subject to the law of impermanence of all things. The sooner you realize that your outer purpose cannot give you lasting fulfillment, the better. When you have seen the limitations of your outer purpose, you give up your unrealistic expectations that it should make you happy, and you make it subservient to your inner purpose."
- /The Power of Now/, Eckhart Tolle

The "conscience" is more than an evolutionary adaptation. It’s a connection to another realm. You are dealing with the "God-shaped vacuum" inside every man. It's not a delusion. Belief in an existence beyond that which we can see is ubiquitous in humans, as well as reasonable. But something does not have to be obvious to be real. We believe in invisible things all the time, in things like air, or in things not in the present, like yesterday and tomorrow. It just takes a little more imagination and work.

The Nihilism of which you spoke, it is the anesthetic of those who have no reason for hope. What’s more, it’s illogical. What point is there to savoring “the now,” much less telling others to do so, if neither of you have a tomorrow? It makes perfect sense how eating, drinking, and "being merry," sex, and drugs, might interest a true nihilist. What does not follow is why you, an apparently congenial type of guy, would go to the effort of pushing a gospel that offers no hope, as this video tries to do. If the proverbial plane is going to crash, and you can't stop it, why spend the trip down making sure everyone knows that they will be wiped out?

But is it as bad as all of that? Some time ago, into this dark, hopeless human experience, a light was dropped. Jesus. (It’s OK to roll your eyes, but keep reading.) The pivotal moment in all history. IF Jesus rose from the dead, there IS hope of life after death. That’s what he claimed. Is there any chance he was right?

And so I ask you…Have you seriously investigated the evidences of his life, death, and resurrection? You won't be able to get him into your laboratory, but there are evidences that the biblical story is true. As far as I know, there is no other religion or philosophy which offers the happy union of truth, hope, and love, all in the same package. Some offer hope and love, but no truth. Some, like you, Derek, offer "truth,” as you see it, and possibly love, but no hope.

The fact that Christianity offers all three, does not in itself, make it so, of course. I'm not saying to just believe something just because you want it to be so. But what I am saying is, given the fact that there's a big "what the hell" about EVERYTHING in a nihilist belief system anyway, why not spend some time sincerely investigating whether or not there is a credible case for the resurrection of Jesus from the dead? Ultimately, there's nothing to lose but time if it turns out to be a blind alley, and even that time is of little consequence if nihilism is valid. On the other hand, you might find, at the end of your search that EVERYTHING has meaning and consequence, that God is the grand unifying theme of all of existence, the physical and the spiritual. Why do all humans have an innate longing to know what is true, if knowing that truth does not benefit them? Why that deep instinct? What if we CAN live forever? Is that thought so profound, that a physicist like yourself could not think it?

Having said all of that, there is a flaw that exists in the mind of even the deepest of men, and it makes otherwise intelligent men stupid. Pride. We see it best in others. “I am my own captain. Then, the physical universe is merely the background for the main event—beings capable of loving of their own volition, actually the only way love can exist. Is that not a noble place in the universe for humans, and one worth celebrating? Unlike the planets, we can CHOOSE to "orbit." Unlike the rocks, we will remain.

Please think about it, Derek.

I agree with other posters here who point out that this comes from a privileged point of view given the claim as to what one "should" be doing. If you're poor, disabled, etc. your options will be more limited. Even without that, what if you lack talent, genetic aptitude, i.e. just on the shitter end of the "normal" bell curve?

I thus like Buddhism philosophy better, or at least the "Thomas Jefferson" version without all the "Buddhaverse" and other weird religious elements (so I don't call myself "a Buddhist" because to me that means accepting as a religion). There are a few simple cold truths about life. None of them indicate a value judgment upon it. Life contains pain. (Not "life IS pain" as some suggest.) Nothing lasts forever. We all are born, grow up, get sick, grow old, and die. All of these can bring us pain. Interestingly at the very beginning this person's analysis sounds very, very much like Buddhism or how the Buddha would have approached. Much as this guy went to the broken down town of Pripyat, the Buddha, 2500 years ago went away from his pleasure-addled rich man's castle out in the world and saw his own cold reminders. People crippled by age, by disease. Dead bodies. Agony. The harsh truths of life. Indeed Buddha would come even to claim things like that, that there is no permanent ego, actually that there is no ego at all. (There were said to be two views, one that there was a permanent ego and another that there was an ego that died, and Buddha said there isn't one to begin with.) There's just things like, what we would now recognize as thoughts, impulses in our brains, matter, body and brains, but no ego to be found in any of these items, or in anything else for that matter.

Buddha also said we can be free of pain by changing our minds -- to avoid that which is wrongful and seek that which is good meaning beneficial to all people and even all other forms of life (at least those that can feel pain themselves), both ourselves and others in equal measure, cultivating moral goodness and a just means to a livelihood, and letting go of excessive, unquenchable desire and egoism as well as refining and focusing our thought processes. Not necessarily free as in that, e.g. a hurt thumb won't hurt (but maybe it may keep us from hurting it in the first place!) but that psychologically, we will not be moved to that which is not good for us any more and to be able to accept things for what they are without trouble, and for others to be made better though it. Life may contain pain but it doesn't have to be about pain and it doesn't have to leave us always wanting more even if we can't actually get more (and that is why I say it's better.).

It is interesting to note that given Buddhist texts, they are not necessarily perfect records of what Buddha actually taught, perhaps subjected to further additions since his time, and regarding death and "afterlives" if any specifically, there seems to be some disagreement in them. In some cases it is claimed that Buddha said that there is a type of rebirth, in others to have said that it cannot be answered and still others that to cling to any theories about it just brings pain or, at least, should not concern one. It is also said though that Buddha would have taught to what would be needed for people to accept his teaching, so it is possible that for some he worked with the existing concepts of rebirth at the time and for others he had to disavow them. Not to upset the cart in some but definitely in others.

(And certainly while one could see how someone whose life is going good may wish for there to be more, I could also equally just as much see how someone depressed or in endless agony could wish for the opposite and wish for just that: the sweet release of oblivion. Depressed, they have no hope for heaven. At least with oblivion, there is no more sadness. And Buddha then is said at some times to have said also that longing for non-existence is just as unhelpful and bad as longing for continued existence.)

(It's even interesting, noting this video author's example of rocks, to note that Buddha also was said to, rather intriguingly presciently although maybe just a lucky guess, have foreseen the end of even the Earth and used that at one point to make a point about the impermanence of things, to show that even the seemingly most-permanent thing ever, the Earth itself, was also not so. And the descriptions he gave sound remarkably like a poetic way of describing the result of the continued evolution of the Sun into a red giant and its final death. He used the image of "seven suns", that there would come a time when two, three, four, and eventually up to seven suns would rise, each one adding heat and evaporating the water from the planet, eventually causing the rock to start to outgas and then finally be incinerated and be consumed until nothing at all remained. One could easily imagine this as seven phases of the further evolution of the Sun, each one hotter and more destructive than the previous. It's not entirely perfect but in any case it is probably the most accurate description of the end of the Earth that I've ever seen in any canon of antiquity.)

The place where the guy in this video doesn't quite make the last cut is the end. For one, not all of us are born with the genetic wherewithal to achieve that which is "great". And even those that do, it too will eventually be forgotten. Such is the universal, all-pervading nature of impermanence. The whole human race's time is limited, the Earth will vanish (as Gautama Siddhartha the Buddha already realized all that time ago in such remarkable detail). The universe itself, will grow cold, empty, and dark. Even if as some theories suggest a new universe will be born to succeed it, no one that comes to be in that universe will have any knowledge of the one which preceded it. And errors won't necessarily be forgotten even for the limited time (cosmically) they are remembered for. MLK Jr. cheated a wife, Malcolm X did some theft. These errors are remembered just as much as their glory. Errors are not forgotten nor are glories; rather we are remembered for exactly the flawed humans we always are. Even our mythological heroes have tragic flaws.

And that as mentioned elsewhere belief in nothing can also be used as an excuse to do something bad. The same idea of being "not cautious" can be taken further. Maybe I can try to do something morally taboo, something evil, dishonest, foul. If I can outsmart and cover it up successfully, then I will die and not have to regret it after that point for I won't exist anymore. Nor will any victim eventually. And I can rationalize it away. Yet simultaneously so can the belief in something continued, e.g. if I believe God will forgive all afterward, then I get to Heaven either way, and so can also do an evil (even better, if I believe God sanctioned it, e.g. ISIS, al Qaeda, or going back further in history the Crusaders and the colonial genocidists of the Age of Genocide.). In other words, belief or non-belief in afterlives, I believe, is less important than how much we really hold on to what is right. At the same time, a belief in something could be used just same, to allow us to be bold as well: if there is something I need not fear losing even if my effort results in my own death. So let's go and take a risk.

(And from my own experience, as someone who cannot make up their mind about afterlives, if they exist or not or what, I've seen both ends, when feeling down or bad how I could wish either for nothing and thus won't have to deal with it ever, or if I feel maybe I did wrong that I might then wonder well what if there is an afterlife and I'll be held to account so maybe I should try and put it right, or how that when I feel energized to do something good, that it would be even better if I could have the opportunity to see the continued results of that good in an afterlife, so that my curiosity will be satisfied. Or then I think that there is nothing, and then also be motivated in that way perhaps like as this guy says, because I'll want the good done so at least it gets done before the nothing.)

In other words, to me the afterlife thing, and consequences of such beliefs, can be argued both ways (and perhaps that is why the Buddha was not of one mind about it and why in some places he suggested that it should not be attended to and maybe that's the answer to the confusion) in both cases. In any case though, there is one thing we can be sure of, afterlife or not : that the time in which we, as us now (even if you accept a reincarnation, you get born as someone else right? Fresh memory and whole new stuff.), have an opportunity to affect the world for good in a direct fashion, is limited. Even if we go to heaven or hell, once we're there we won't be able to do whatever we wanted to here. So why not do good for someone else now ? I guess though that's the conclusion at the end of the video as well (although the visual hints suggest toward a kind of class-privileged idea of "what you should do" which is wrong and doesn't focus on the more collectivistic style of thought which is in many ways more just because we can always try to do something for other people in whatever capacities we are given and find reward in that, even if we can't go climb 60 tall mountains due to lack of $ or invent the greatest invention ever due to lack of intellectual giftedness.). But the funny part is, it doesn't really depend on whether you believe that there is things after death or not; because of the fact I mentioned above, that whether there is or isn't, the fact is you die and thus are removed from the position you were in where you could do that, whether to go off to a heaven or hell, or to be reincarnated as someone who in important ways really isn't "you" anymore (won't have the same wants, needs, outlook, or whatever), or simply end up as nothing.

I still remember the first time I realized I was going to die because it evoked such an visceral, paralyzing fear.

I was probably nine, ten, eleven, some young-ish age like that, and I was lying in bed about to go to sleep, imagining what it would be like to be an earthworm, underground and surrounded by dirt. My imagination painted such a vivid picture that it almost made me feel like I'd had a "past life" where perhaps I was an earthworm. This concept suddenly flipped a switch, causing the realisation that if that was a "past life" had ended, the one I was currently living would end one day too and the mystery of what would happen when I died. I remember crying and being unable to move or fall asleep for hours. The fear only went away when I read a comic book to delude myself again that everything would be alright.

The way I realized sounds so ridiculous, but I'd be curious to know how other people came to confront their own mortality for the first time. It's really a maturing moment as soon as you realize that you will die and everyone/everything you know and love will die too.

I love your video, Bryan, because of the very fundamental points it hits on that people rarely contemplate. I think you have drawn logical conclusions, but I am sure that they are completely wrong. :) I'll elaborate.

Records about as ancient as the human species itself and experiences of millions of people even today show that we are actually hardwired to experience nothingness. The experience is usually not described as non-existence, but as eternal, undifferentiated pure existence (no specific objects but the pure potentiality of all existences). This connects to unified field theories of theoretical physics. It's an experience of pure abstraction, but the experience of nothingness itself is concrete nonetheless (otherwise it wouldn't have been recorded throughout history).

Research has shown that there is a unique 4th state of consciousness that is called transcendental consciousness, the experience of which would accurately be described as nothingness, completely without any notion of space and time. It's pure awareness without an object of perception besides itself -- self-referential awareness.
It is characterized by a combination of low arousal and high attention (the reverse of what is typically seen), also called a state of restful alertness. It's a state where the mind is completely unperturbed, completely in rest, yet alert and wakeful within itself.
During the experience of this 4th state, global EEG coherence is measured -- i.e. synchronized functioning in the entire brain -- indicating more orderly and integrated functioning, which has been correlated with peak performance in top athletes and entrepeneurs. No other experience is known to produce brainwave coherence at this scale.

The nuance here is that nothingness is directly experienced in pure consciousness, not through sensory perception. It is experienced by directing the attention inward instead of outward (through the senses), and this can be done reliably in a systematic and spontaneous way, not involving imagination or suggestion or any sort of control of the mind. In my opinion this shows that we are hardwired for the experience.
The only reason why most people have not experienced it is that they don't know of a way to turn the attention within without effort, which is essential because effort keeps the mind active on superficial levels of consciousness. Transcendental Meditation is the only method I know that offers a reliable effortless technique to provide the experience of pure consciousness, completely regardless of a person's tendencies.

Identity is also a sort of delusion. We call a rock 'a rock', but a rock, of course, does not consider itself 'a rock', nor can 'it' tell itself apart from the many atoms or protons or quarks that make it up. Only we do that. Likewise with ourselves. What we consider 'permanent' is not permanent even from one moment to the next.

Consider yourself as you were when you were two years old. If you removed that consciousness from your body then and placed it in another child's body now, would you say that child is you or effectively another person? The individual there is so radically different from yourself now, and you have forgotten so much about that individual's own self-awareness at the time, that it could effectively be considered as different as another person. In that sense we do actually experience 'death' of a sort as we age by way of simple change. Yet most of us would say the person who existed in an earlier state of our body when we were five is 'still alive' - as if that person had somehow persisted rather than perished. The person perished, but it was so gradual that we didn't notice.

We say we fear death, yet we generally tolerate the sort of death brought by gradual change very well. We actually want to continue changing, evolving, even though in so doing - even if we live forever - the very act of changing would radically transform us again, and 'we' - as we are right now, as we imagine ourselves, our current sense of awareness - would still disappear into the mists of time, and so we would 'die' anyway.

So whether you exist or not depends very strongly on what you are defining as 'you'. For me it is easier to imagine nothingness by imagining a single photon. A photon exists from our perspective, but it cannot from its own - so it is a sort of nothing. It cannot in any way have a sense of itself and if nothing were around to interact with it, I question whether we could say it exists at all. It is a thing that is only a thing insofar as it is observed. It cannot be a thing to itself because it experiences no time.

This also relates to the 'God' paradox. Having an omniscient and omnipotent being - all-knowing, all-powerful - is a bit like having an infinite speed of light for the universe, where all parts of the universe can then interact with and 'know' each other instantly. This inhibits discreteness and since it is its own alpha and omega, actually inhibits anything we would call consciousness at all. God would be exactly like the individual photon - since such a being would experience no time and could thus not exist in relation to anything else, it could have no awareness, no purpose and no consciousness. So it wouldn't be an awareness at all. God in this total sense is a logical impossibility. You can have a 'god' that is fully aware of a system it is not bound by. Draw a flat 'universe' on paper and decide how its constituents will move and you are 'god' for that universe, but it is only possible insofar as you exist beyond that universe you created, in another one for which you are not and cannot be 'god' - where you do not know everything - otherwise you would cease to be aware at all as you would be everything all at once and unable to interact with anything outside yourself, unable to 'change' in relation to yourself over time.

So, amazingly, while we fear our mortality, it also seems that the awareness we so cherish is actually physically impossible without it - not just in this universe, but in any universe.

This idea has haunted me from a small child, as far back as I can remember. I can imagine non-existence and it terrifies me beyond measure. I know that at one point I did not exist, and therefore it is possible for me to not exist again. Not drifting through endless blackness alone, but to be nothing. If this has never scared you, then I truly believe you’ve never thought about it hard enough (most people don’t).

How do we go on knowing that our lives and our legacy will surely fade? That our children’s lives will fade? That some day all human achievement and significance will fade to nothingness?

Something that helps me is this question: Without a conscious witness, does the universe exist? This is an extension of the famous question; “If a tree falls in the forest, does it make a sound?” With modern science we know that sound waves carry over long distances and their vibration percolates through the surrounding matter causing slight but very real friction and reactions. Yes, the tree does make a sound because its shockwave of ‘noise’ budged a single leaf 1mm, and that is measurable. Does a meteor crashing into a planet a billion light years from any living thing make an impact? Yes, even the slightest photon of light from the impact flies through the universe and delivers its energy elsewhere. Due to the infinite subtlety of the universe, the answer is always ‘yes’. That is, until you get to the larger picture. The largest picture. Without a conscious being to witness its passing, the scope of time is meaningless. A star’s birth and death is instantaneous without something to put it in perspective. Like color, time only exists as it is perceived. You might say “well, this star lived 1 million years longer than this star, so we can compare their lifespan as a measurement of time”, however without a single being to witness it (and present that argument), they never existed at all.

So, life does have meaning - without it, the universe isn’t even a theory. If our little planet is the only life in the universe then the universe exists for us, because of us. Many believe that other life is probable in the universe. With the trillions of stars and galaxies, it seems absurdly probable that life bloomed elsewhere. However, how rare is ‘intelligent life’? How many years and how many species did it take to produce us? And we barely made it. There is a chance that we are the first - the only beings to ever look up at the stars and measure things, to contemplate our place among the vastness. To be human, to be you, is exceedingly significant.

While I appreciate the message of this video and generally agree with what Mr. Muller is trying to say; the feeling/ belief/ mental state of understanding one's own mortality that is being described is simply not nihilism.

'Nihilism' ('nihil' being literally 'nothing'/ 'none' in Latin) describes a subset of many different subjects. There are moral/ ethical nihilists, epistemological nihilists, ontological/ metaphysical nihilists, etc. In each case, nihilism is the stance which rejects the validity of subject as a whole by claiming that there is no subject/ nothing being investigated. So, moral nihilism is based upon the belief that there is NO morality to be studied, therefore ALL moral/ ethical systems are wrong (yes, this includes uber-libertarian ego-centrism as well); while epistemic nihilism rejects epistemology (the study/ theory of knowledge and what qualifies to be accurately described as knowledge) on the basis that knowledge does not exist; and metaphysical/ ontological nihilism goes so far as to be based on a rejection of the existence of existence itself.

What is mentioned in this video (an acceptance with one's own status as a temporal and temporary being, as opposed to the delusion of seeing oneself as, so some extent or another, eternal) neither rejects either the acceptance of or the rejection of this mental state, so it cannot, strictly speaking, be called nihilist/ nihilism. From what's available, it sounds like Mr. Muller is probably describing one of the more humanist forms of existentialism, but that's as specific as I can be, considering how little I know of his actual stance and the fact that I'm by no means expert in existentialist theory.

Everything we understand is through processed sensory contrast (up vs down, dark vs light, hot vs cold, fast vs slow good vs bad) and that's where all value is derived. One could surmise that all values and experiences are like an abstract division of zero into positive and negative values, that our entire existence is simply a finite abstraction. But, one could just as reasonable assume that values are derived rather than contrived; that all of our hopes and all of our dreams, are more than material which decays with time. Perhaps we experience meaning because there's an infinite availability of it everywhere. I find the inspiration that comes from the idea of an infinite existence where consciousness journeys on forever is much greater than the meaningless void I've started to slide into.

Thinking that existence itself is finite vs infinite also seems like an assumption. The singularity is said to have been infinite heat, density and mass. Doesn't sound so finite after all, for heat is molecular motion and time is a sequence of events, therefore it follows that infinite heat means that existence is infinite and something has always existed. What if origins do not exist? What if there's simply an infinite chain of cause and effect? To even logically suppose the universe ultimately came did not come from "nothing" is written off as being incorrect since logic itself is seen as dependent on the existence of the universe as it is now. This is a logical judgement against logic judgements, and therefore just as much an assumption as the idea logic is immutable.

Regardless of whether you agree, there is a big, scary universe out there. So I wish you every blessing in your pursuit of truth.

One day, as I was just thinking, I wandered into the topic of religion, the purpose of life (etc.), as we had been covering that recently in my classes. I grew up religious as a child. I had never thought much of it or why I'm alive, but as we studied this topic, I started probing around. I asked myself the question, why do I exist? The first response was almost automatic: to behave myself for the afterlife, heaven (etc.).
However, I started probing deeper. I had begun to shift away from being religious at this time in my life, so I started to try to think of a possible secondary reason. I drew a blank. I couldn't think of anything at all. Humans are programmed to reproduce, I thought. But why? Reproduction is just an endless cycle. You produce offspring so humans can live on and create more and more and more. I was truly stumped as to why that would be necessary though.
And then the thought came: Maybe we have no purpose, maybe there is no reason we're here. I was terrified. There must be a purpose, I thought. But the more I pondered, the more I began to accept that I may have no real purpose. After all, humans are just a honed combination of the correct compatible elements. We don't have some special origin or distinction from anything else that is abiotic, we just got lucky.
Once I had accepted this rationale, I felt alone. Almost everyone I know is religious. Almost everyone I know... believed something radically different. I began to regain my sanity though. Sure, I might just live for awhile and die; the end. But that doesn't mean that I can't enjoy my life. I felt like the strongest way to attack this fear of uselessness was to accept it.

"Our Greatest Delusion" right after a video featuring Richard Dawkins, author of "The God Delusion." It doesn't take a genius to understand what this video is really about. I believe that this is a closed off way of perceiving our world.

We've been focusing so long on Science that we've lost sight of its other half: Philosophy. We've written off our consciousness as a perfectly natural phenomena, yet we understand so little of how it works. Our brains aren't the biggest, nor are they the biggest in relation to our bodies. We share >95% of our DNA with Chimps, yet we have this supernatural ability to understand concepts like morals and emotions. And as far as we know, we are the only species in the universe that possesses this unique trait. That certainly makes us something special in a cosmic sense.

Science has gotten us this far, but I believe it's coming to a standstill. There have been no scientific breakthroughs in the past hundred years, with the exception of the untestable String Theory (doesn't sound very scientific though, does it?), despite our unprecedented connectedness in the Information Age. We, as humans, desire to know, but there are some things that will always be beyond our understanding. We will never know what lies beyond the event horizon of a black hole, or the exact position and momentum of a particle, or where the mass that exploded into our universe came from. I believe, similarly, we will never know what exists for us after death. For the time being, we have two theories, and neither should be written off as impossible until it is known for certain. This is the core principle of the scientific method and what has gotten us to this point in our history. Atheists think they "know" despite a lack of evidence just the same as theists do.

The only truly scientific standpoint, in my opinion, is agnosticism, but I'm not one for fence sitting. I think--or I hope--that Philosophy will see a revival in the next hundred years. I want to see theories like Christopher Langan's CTMU being discussed in academic settings and great thinkers like CS Lewis being read by people other than Christians and meditation being practiced in the West. It has nothing to do with evolution, it's a thought experiment. Sure evolution makes us fear death, but it's not what makes eternal oblivion incomprehensible. Here is the question: if we can truly die, than how are we alive at all? How can a finite amount of "something" be selected from an infinite expanse of "nothing"? To make a probabilities, a metaphysical model of the universe is needed that can exist with different variables among a probability distribution. Any atheistic model of the universe runs into one of two problems. The first is that consciousness is too easy,  meaning a simple solipsistic world is more probable than a complex sensory one, ala Boltzmann brains. The other problem is that consciousness would be way too hard, the probabilities of a universe capable of consciousness forming being astronomical. This is solved via the anthropic principle: we live in a universe capable of supporting conscious life because otherwise we wouldn't be observing it. But, if the anthropic principle can be used once, then why can't it be used again? It should grant us the same immortality that it grants our existence in the first place. Granted, this wouldn't guarantee keeping our memories by any means, but consciousness would have to live on, if not in this universe, than in some universe. Really the issue is your idea of nothing is inadequate, it's a physical nothing, not a psychic nothing, which is truly incomprehensible.  If anything, evolution should make us believe in oblivion, because if we believe death is not the end, then why should we fear death? So rather, the greatest delusional is not that we are eternal, but that anything is, including oblivion.

Derek, your philosophy is interesting, but there is a flaw in to consider in your ideas—especially in light of science.

From this video, and others of yours, it appears that you believe there is no such thing as an "eternal soul," or "God"/"gods," or "spirituality," etc. And it seems you believe that way because science has nothing to say about these ideas.

You talk about rocks in this video, and I'm a geology major. In this day and age, almost everyone is familiar with the theory of plate tectonics. But this theory was not generally accepted by the scientific community until the 1950's. Before then, those who did consider plate tectonics were called lunatics and rejected; and before that science had nothing to say about plate tectonics. So let me ask you this: did plate tectonics exist before science had anything to say about it? The answer is yes of course. So because science has yet to discover how the spiritual may interact with the physical, does that mean that there is no such thing as the spiritual?

Just because science has not yet discovered something—or how it works—this does not mean that it must therefore be false, untrue, or non-existent.

Please note I am NOT saying that "spirituality must exist because we can't disprove it." All I am saying though is that you cannot claim these ideas false on the basis of science. You must leave other possibilities open. Because if you do claim that it is false on the basis of science, you claim that science must know everything. And just think about how much science is discovering each year! The amount of information is almost unfathomable. What if the scientific explanations of the "spiritual" simply lie within the undiscovered?

I don't write this comment to "prove you wrong" or something, but rather I write in that there is much more to this philosophical discussion than the ideas you have presented. At this point, neither of us can claim that the ideas we have presented are completely and fully true (there's only so much you can discuss in a 7 minute video, and youtube comment). And we must be open to discuss other possibilities and explanations—just like in science.

The philosophical assertions expressed in this video rely on a staggering number of postulates about things that are unobserved, non-observable, or intangible.
Starting with the idea of nihilism, you run into it's friend existentialism, that is, there is no meaning except that which we make. "We procrastinate living the life we truly desire..." But as a cloud of particles thinking itself eternal, desire isn't really anything more than a chemical reaction, is it? And satisfaction of desire met equally so, and disappointment equally so, and meaning, and legacy, and freedom, slavery, even thought and logic and knowledge... all chemical reactions you label "delusion" occurring in a cloud of chance particles which really contains less information than your average gamma-ray background noise sample. (as you've stated yourself, random signal is more information than organized signal)

In this I would call you out on a greater delusion: that your knowledge means anything. Realistically, the only things you really enjoy are dopamine and seratonin. Your wonder at your perceived knowledge, and observations as you see them, trigger their release and you attribute some temporal meaning to the event. Is this really any different from the religious fanatic, or the lunatic with a pleasant hallucination? All are temporary reactions that will run their course, a deluded sense of "experience" that will perish as your meat sack ceases functionality and decays.

In essence it seems you took 7 and a half minutes to say "We won't exist soon, so do something that will also not exist soon." Because, as you simultaneously assert, the rocks we etch epitaphs in, and the stars we look up and dream upon will burn out and lose their ascribed meaning as well. You end where you start. Of course not, since I am the agent of my own life and happiness. I should not "be afraid" to do any of this. A million years from now, it's not going to matter if I were a saint or a monster. If errors and humiliation are forgotten, but great achievements are not, what if the great achievement I wish to achieve is to go down in history as a murderer? 99% of the people who lived in the late 1800s are gone, forgotten, not even mourned. But people remember Jack the Ripper. What if I am to "make my own meaning" that way? What if that's what I should "get busy" doing?

I've heard it said "If you need a God to give you morals, then what you lack is empathy." But in a nihilistic framework, of what use is empathy, unless it is something that makes you happy? What if you don't desire to be empathic with others? What if empathy doesn't make you happy, and sadism does? Should I not be "cowardly" and embrace my desires in that way? I've yet to hear a logical argument to debunk it. Sure, I've heard the argument that if we all acted that way, society would break down, and we'd end up degenerating into barbarism. But why should I care about that, unless it affects me? If I "make my own meaning" of my own life, shouldn't I also "make my own meaning" of other people's lives, too? Unless their lives give me some sort of pleasure, they are meaningless and should be eliminated, since they're wasting my resources. And the resources, the people, the world is all mine, because I am the most important thing on it, in my view. Because my days are numbered, I should get busy with eliminating any competition I have, because my time to do what I want is running out, and I'll have more of it if I have more resources, which others are taking for themselves.

That's the way I see nihilism. That's why I wonder if anyone truly wants everyone to "make their own meaning" because every person's "meaning" is going to conflict with someone else's "meaning" in the process.

Actually, this notion isn't 100% nihilism --
The conclusion of this video, that you're ending in nothingness, that because of that your life in a sense has little meaning, and yet, that you live knowing exactly that, giving your life meaning, is the quintessence of absurdism.
The name absurdism stems from the 'the absurd' - whick is defined as knowing that life is meaningless, but struggling to give it sense none the less.

One of the greatest absurdist minds was Albert Camus.
He compares life to the tale of Sisyphus who is punished by the gods - he has to push a boulder up a hill every day, but when he reaches the top, it rolls back down again - so this whole ordeal is kind of senseless.
But, I quote Camus: "The struggle itself towards the height is enough to fill a man's heart. One must imagine Sisyphus happy."

Something to consider:

We exist between certain physical and temporal coordinates. If I were to ask if someone exists, answering that question would require me to observe the correct place in spacetime.

One cannot meaningfully discuss space without discussing time. That's why we have the concept of spacetime to begin with. Our bodies exist somewhere on line t (time), and at every point along t that we exist, our bodies exist somewhere spatially on the x, y, and z axis.

Given all this, isn't it odd that we have so much anxiety about the fact that we don't exist along the totality of t? We have no anxiety about the fact that we don't exist across all of the x, y, or z axises. We are comfortable with the fact that most of space is not-us. If space and time are really so inseparable that we cannot meaningfully discuss one without discussing the other, then why does it bother us so much that so much of time is also not-us?

I think there's an immortality hidden here, though it's a different kind of immortality that the impossible desire to exist across all of time without also existing across all of space. Rather, it's the realization that one exists at some points on x, y, z, and t, and one will always exist at those points. People in the past and future may not know what exactly existed at those spacetime coordinates, but that does not nullify the fact that you always have, and always will, exist there.

Perhaps there's some solace in that.

This presents the Nihilist's Paradox, as I like to call it (a variation of the classic paradox of nihilism), which is as follows:
True Nihilism can never be spread from person to person by a true Nihilist. The true nihilist would never try to propagate their philosophy, because there would be no point, and because their philosophy implies the meaninglessness of their own philosophy. Thus, the only people you will ever hear talk about nihilism at all are not true nihilists. They like to think they don't believe in meaning, but they sense enough meaning in the universe to want to propagate their idea.
 
Nihilism is not disprovable, but one should never need to disprove nihilism. This is because a nihilist cannot argue their position without contradicting it in their speech. Thus, if you ever find yourself arguing with a nihilist about nihilism, take solace in the fact that you have already won the argument.

However, if you have 'infinite' time then for example the next big bang can be fairly reliably predicted to happen within the time frame of 10^10^10^56 years somewhere within the confines of the ever expanding universe. The mathematics to determine how long any given subatomic portion of matter would have to wait to individually experience a similar event is too large the bother calculating, but it doesn't matter because the probability DOES exist, and with infinite time its bound to occur 'eventually'.

What does this mean? Well it means every subatomic portion of you is bound to be caught up in a new universe eventually (Albeit with the same physical properties as our own since this 'big bang' is not the result of a new universe creation event but just the probability of a number of virtual particles 'happening' to diverge and appear with significant enough initial starting conditions and positions to form the same results as a big bang).

Here's the catch though... Although all parts of you will find their existence continued in new universes, those parts are unlikely to be in any way connected or influenced by any other parts of you, the world you knew, or anyone in it you ever knew. To put it in your perspective, the scales of time being discussed are so vast that quite literally no part of any particle that was part of you will be in any way connected with any particle that was part of your entire initial universe.

I don't deny that it's quite possible that's all there is in the end, but I hope, and oftentimes believe, there's more. Hope is my compass, and to travel in the direction it points to, my nihilism is more targeted. It takes the form of analytical criticism - of institutional and cultural authority. Why do we have to do things this way? What's really going on here? Many of life's mysteries are simply the intended or unintended results of other people's choices to act or not act in certain ways, perhaps generations ago, whether they had certain knowledge or not. Once you realize how relatively little personal control you have over your life in the global sense, let alone cosmic, it becomes quite liberating actually, because you and "the most powerful people on earth" are actually pretty much on the same playing field in terms of your human capabilities and potentials. We all die, so we all live with the paradox of finitie amounts of time and infinite imaginations. Realizing it was always that way makes it possible to imagine and realize a better here and now for yourself and others. There's no natural hierarchy or social order, only that which we construct so as to improve the lives and legacies of ourselves and fellow human beings. So, why settle for a crappy version? Why not be more equitable in love in the here and now? That's where any hope of transcendence lies, whether you believe over time or outside of time, either way beyond our own individual experiences. I'm not advocating one -ism or -cracy system over another, only pointing out they all have the same vulnerabilities and challenges because they're all inventions of human beings. We live, fight and die by what are ultimately delusions, all the time. Why not at least live by the paradigm that the only thing worth living for, risking death for, is the present? We need to constantly be critical, creative, inspirational, compassionate, empathetic, because only those things improve our present - our relationships with each other, or at least offer the hope of ultimately doing so. They put the drops in, gave me some tests, and sent me out with some sunglasses and told me not to take them off for a while. I took them off. It was an overcast day and not very bright out. When I took the sunglasses off what I discovered was that everything around me was much more beautiful than I'd ever seen before, because more light was entering my eye. That light was always there I just never saw it because we're built to filter it out. So that beauty is always there, always. But we rarely see it. At some point we figured out how to change our mechanism to let more light in so that we could get glasses. That sure was good for me. I would never have known otherwise. Thankfully I could already see with my eyes, without a frame with which to understand what was happening I think that the experience would have been useless - how could I even take it in? I really hate messages like this one. Ones that, at the start, appear very analytical, very sincere and objective. Indeed, your conclusion perpetuates the very delusion you so eloquently point out in your intro.

The only reason you choose to continue to exist, acknowledging that we have no true meaning in this universe, is because you choose to believe that the experiences you have as a human are potentially worth having. To that end, your conclusion is nonsensical. Those who are "afraid" to undertake the actions you mention, do so because they think caution is the optimal method for improving the experiences they have as a human. Your emboldened objectives are identical to the cautious objectives of others, they are merely informed by different biases.

I don't know if the true intent behind this video was to attempt to dispel the delusion you mention. However, I feel your conclusion is completely contradictory to a Nihilistic perspective. In my opinion, true Nihilism would dictate that, with regards to the manner in which you live your life, it simply does not matter. It is irrelevant.

While I agree that it is important to realize the true transience of our lives and act by making the most of every moment, I fundamentally disagree with adopting existential nihilism as a means of justification. 
I think the nihilism described in this video is a watered-down version of what it really means to be nihilist.  
True nihilism, at least existential nihilism, is the belief that life is meaningless; that there is no point in living. After all, we are going to die, so what difference does it make?
That is what I think when I hear nihilism. Its a destructive and unhealthy way to live your life because the very thing you will ever do is pointless. Anything you do or receive, including embarrassment and achievements are idle under this belief. Although the interpretation in the video is not as extreme, I still think it is a poor and frightening way to justify living in the moment.

On a side note, I would agree that the actions one makes in their life will ultimately be nothing to them when in an eternal oblivion, but it does not mean the repercussions are not nothing when they are alive. I don't think one should await death to ameliorate one's problems.

The delusion of permanence includes and hides the delusion of stability, consistency. In the contemplation of nothingness as the ‘end’ to ‘us’ we still take ‘us’ as a consistent whole stable object in space and time. The realization that ones life is finite is a crack in the delusion of permanence, but it itself relies on the delusion of consistency. That the ‘I’ of my infancy and the ‘I’ of my adoloence and the ‘I’ of my present typing are in some way the same ‘thing.’
But this is not rationally the case. We may fail to see rocks as dynamic because the processes that transform them are so slow, but we can not fail to see ourselves and all life as fundamentally dynamic. We eat, breathe, work and sweat. Our bodies are systems of systems that ultize matter from the outside to provide energy to continue operating. We exist, at every moment, the merely most recent result of a process.
For me the delusion is that ‘I’ a thing at all. What I gather up when I reflect on myself as ‘I’ is the contingent result of million interactions that led to that moment. ‘I’ bare a relation to previous ‘I’s but it merely the relation of cause and effect. My ten year old self is no more mentally ‘me’ than it is materially so. My body is composed of different and more matter than that boy. My mind is the result of twenty more years of experience and decisions. I am because of that boy, but I am not that boy.
For me, this is where the vision of the end breaks down. To say that I end when my body dies is arbitrary; anyone outside observer would see that my body is still fully dynamic engaged with the processes of the world. The people I’ve loved, influenced, helped, their lives continue contingent on my influence. I have, at every moment, the power to change the world.
In nature, we see that things do not begin and end. Processes operate in cycles. Winter comes, only to be overcome by Spring and then to return at the end of Summer. It makes no sense to think of ‘ends’ in this reality, but it makes equally little sense to label any object in the processes a stable, consistent or permanent thing.

I'm not really looking to get into the whys and wherefores of faith or theism at this time of night, but I do want to say I don't think you should go promoting nihilism.  Not because of its truth or untruth, but strictly because of its effect on the human psyche, and by extension, society as a whole.  To wit:

Nihilism, or for that matter the hardcore "scientific" atheism of a Richard Dawkins (as opposed to the gentler agnosticism of, say, Terry Pratchett) maintains that the only reality is the physical one.  I seldom see its proponents follow this out to its natural conclusion, though - that if this is the case, then A) I should do whatever I can to prolong my own life, because it is all that is left to me; and B) human life has no intrinsic value, and so I should feel free to do exactly as I please to my fellow beings, as long as I don't get caught.  If this sounds psychopathic, that's because it is. 

Conclusion A says that, if I am out on a life raft with a 5-year-old, I should absolutely eat him rather than possibly die myself.  Moreover, it says I should feel neither hesitation prior to this act nor remorse afterward - neither of us has any more intrinsic value than, for example, an electron in one of our atoms.  Like me, he came into this world as a result of a set of physical reactions, and he will go out the same way, and the universe does not care.  There is no "him", with all that "him" implies - there is only "it".

Conclusion B says that, if the 5-year-old were instead a young woman, I should forcefully and repeatedly satisfy myself on her first, before (or possibly while) eating her.  There is no chance of getting caught for this act, as we are out at sea and I plan to eat most of her and chuck what's left into the ocean.  And, again, there is nothing wrong with this - her life has no value, and her fear is only a chemical reaction, no more significant than the fizz of vinegar and baking soda.  Again, there is no "her" - there is only "it". 

This is the same "it" you would use to reference a rock you will smash to make gravel for your driveway.  It might be the same "it" you use to reference the worm on your hook or the fish you will cook for dinner.  But it is also the same "it" that you hear in "It puts the lotion in the basket..." 

And that's the problem with promoting nihilism.  There are a lot of really nasty things I would absolutely do if I thought that 1) people didn't matter, and 2) I could get away with it.  Maybe this isn't the case with everyone, but I have to think it probably is for most.  And I'm a reasonably smart guy, so I could probably think of a way to do this stuff without repercussions.  There are two things that stop me: 

First, I believe that someone is always aware of me.  Whether that is a Someone or just a someone, like my father or grandfathers, I don't know or care; but I definitely feel that what I do matters, and that a day will come when I will be proud or ashamed of what I did with my whole life, even the parts that were seemingly secret at the time.  Second, and more importantly, I am not a psychopath.  I think that people have an intrinsic value, beyond the purely physical, beyond their utility to my needs.  And so I would starve myself to give the 5-year-old the last of the food and water.  And I would control myself with the young woman, and if I did do something that caused her to react with fear of me, I would feel ashamed of myself. 

From a purely rational standpoint, this makes no sense - as a man in his prime, I have a better chance of surviving until rescue than either of them.  From an evolutionary stance, I should take every opportunity to spread my genetic material (though eating its recipient might put a damper on my chances of procreation.)  But most importantly, if everything is just physics, their lives have no value, other than what they can provide to me.  And that's just as true in the suburbs as it is in the lifeboat.  Like I said, I could figure out a way to not get caught.

So there are two takeaways here: First, if the ship is sinking, and you see Richard Dawkins in your lifeboat, grab a float and take your chances swimming.  Second, it might not be a good idea to generally promote nihilism - your first sign of success might be when your neighbor poisons you for your new vacuum cleaner.

An interesting though is that nihilism doesn't seem to allow for life to have inherent value. For if death means true nothingness, it can't really be said to be better or worse than being alive. From the perspective of living person you typically want to continue living, and feel compelled to do so, but a dead person cannot wish to be alive, and cannot regret his death, thus being alive cannot truly be said to be a "better" state.

How then, can death be said to be significant for the person who died? How can death be seen as a tragic event without referring to how it affects the people who knew that person, and thus must experience grief; or the loss of a practical contributor to society? If someone without family, friends or practical usefulness were to die, can this be said to be a tragic event by any means in the philosophy of nihilism?

Note that I'm not criticizing the philosophy, just exploring some of its implications.

There are strong epistemological reasons to believe that empirical forms of knowledge are not absolute, nor do they precede a priori reasoning. Nihilism is, in a sense, scepticism gone mad.. I am reminded of a quote by Max Planck, it goes something like, "Science will never solve the ultimate mystery of nature, for in the final analysis, we ourselves are a part of the mystery that we are trying to solve. Anyone who has been seriously engaged in scientific work realises that over the entrance to temple of science are written the words: Ye must have faith. It is a quality that any scientist cannot dispense with." The reason for this is simply because science deals with seemingly inert physical entities that derive from the particular kind of conscious experience known to humans. This is nothing mystical.. We clearly must use the tools and intellectual ability with which we find ourselves with to decipher this great experience we call nature. It's analysis is science, a purely naturalistic methodology. But that's not everything. We choose how we define words and scientific concepts.. Change the meanings of those words and you change your entire world-view. When you realise that nature is not a set of words, and that words and theories and proofs are simply labels for patterns in a reality our intellect is too unreal to derive, you will see that, yes, everything is impermanent--your mind, your body, the planet--but you can bet your life that there is something permanent, somewhere, somehow. Some substance that is too primitive to be called a thing--a quantum vacuum or a universal wave-function, who knows. Combine this with the direction academic philosophy of science is heading, which is to say, away from reductionist physicalism and towards some kind of physicalistic property dualism or panpsychism (I don't personally believe these are true, but they are a stepping stone), there is every reason in the world to believe that some sort of protoexperiential quality exists within the ultimate fabric of space and time. If you can identify with that, then you might find some ethic in it. Which is more than we can say for nihilism, which, remember, asserts that morality, love, kindness, sharing, and all intrinsic values, are abstractly contrived illusions.
