I hope your video will inspire some people to take ownership of their lives. Unfortunately, I think for many of us, the psychology of it is a lot more complicated than believing that there is no life after this one. For one thing, I think it's something you have to experience, viscerally, and then it has to stick with you. If you only experience it once or twice and then forget, or you only ever acknowledge it as an intellectual belief, then it will no more change your mind than believing in a heaven will.

The other thing is, the fear, and the things that fuel it, can be very complicated defense mechanisms and can be influenced by traumas, by brain "defects," and so on.

I think that "your truth" that you are putting forth is one useful way to reach the end goal of taking ownership of one's life and meeting fear head on. But there are numerous other ways to reach that end goal and some of them involve religion (I'm an atheist, btw - this is not an attempt to evangelize).

I think people fear nihilism because they fear a world devoid of meaning. But in reality, I doubt there's a single living nihilist whose life is completely devoid of meaning and maintains that sensibility for an extended period of time. It seems it's simply a matter of finding meaning in impermanence, rather than permanence; human connection and compassion, helpfulness that will outlast one's lifespan, etc., the main difference being the belief that one's impact and life will always be remembered by someone or something, versus believing that one's impact and life will inevitably fade and disappear.

But since it is so difficult to conceptualize the latter with any sort of lasting understanding, I think the humanitarian nihilist and the humanitarian theist wind up looking much the same.

Devout religion is another matter entirely, since it can involve things like intrusive evangelizing; that's a can of worms I have no desire to open.

If we were all truly deluded that we were eternal, what reason would there be not to put a bullet in your head once you've raised your kids, lived your dreams and had your fun rather than suffering for years to come in a sack of meat that is slowly but surely dying? 

You say that we are afraid of doing things because failure would stick with us, but it is the opposite. We take caution because failure would end us. If you believe that you'll continue should the worst happen, what penalty is there in failure? Video games show this well; give someone unlimited respawns and they'll jump into all the holes to see what secrets may lie below, but give them one life and they'll forget about the secrets and continue on with care. So there is no delusion, apart from among the extremely devout or ignorant. We are acutely aware of our own mortality and that is evident in nearly everything we do.

It's certainly an interesting topic that's for sure. Many people get attached to the idea of one or another. I can feel this within myself too. Even though I do respect and appreciate the video, personally, I am inclined to believe that the soul is eternal. I do not want to attach myself to anything, I do not wish to argue, but I will give an intelligent response to your video.

The debate between theist and atheist has been going on for thousands of years. There have always been people who do not believe in a higher existence, in a god. And there have always been people who do believe in them. People have used thousands of arguments back and forth. They have used really good, really compelling arguments aswell. But none of them have ever wiped out both atheism or theism. The arguments are there. If you believe in a god or a higher existence, then your search will be for the arguments in favor of god and against the non-existence of it. If you don't believe in him, it will be the opposite. 

The problem is that most people are not willing to really listen to the arguments that go opposed to their beliefs. Their beliefs become part of them, part of their self. In a sense, being proven wrong is to die. This is why people barely ever listen to each other when they come at each other with opposing beliefs. Everybody is just there to prove themselves right and the opposing team wrong. They don't care about being right, they care about being acknowlegded as right.

Most of us in the west thinks of people in the east as naive idiots for all their religiousness and spirituality. We may not say that about them, but we think that. Conversely, they think us as fools for believing we have only one life with (at least in their eyes) such clear and compelling evidence of god. It's really a matter of how we were conditioned to view the world as.

I am not trying to let people believe that god exists, but since I feel there are much more atheists then theists (I use theist in the sense that the person beliefs in something higher than him/herself), I will provide arguments simply to consider for people who belief that a higher existence does not exist. If this was a video where people were mainly theists, I could have provided arguments that indicate the opposite. Simply because I do not want people to attach themselves to one another.

One of the most compelling questions that I have asked myself lately is this one: With all this scientific research going on, then why, if god or something higher would exist, has his existence or traces of his existence not been proven by science?

I have given this much thought and the most fertile answer I have found is that people simply will not go to that which they do not want to belief. Another good one is that god may not be proven or tested since he is a completely subjective, immaterial phenomenon, something which lab testing can not reach.

But let me paint you this picture, let's just imagine, just for this thought-experiment, that paranormal phenomena do exist: From all the scientific researches that have been done, just a small percentage are being done about a subject that could possibly indicate a higher existence than the material world we live in. (like paranormal phenomena). Most of those experimets are problably done with a skeptic attitude, people eager to disprove it. Let's say it's about telekinesis, the ability to move objects with one's mind. Problably most of the subjects invited to prove this phenomena through scientific research do not have any psychic powers. The ones that do have them, are possibly too nervous or unwilling to show them in front of scientists.
Then you remain with a small percentage of a small percentage who are showing the scientists that their supposed fable is an actual reality, by moving a glass or table for instance. 

Now you have a bunch of astounded scientists. Some of them refuse to believe what they have just witnessed, they simply will not allow them to belief otherwise even though they have seen it with their own eyes. Others admit that they are not sure, and again other scientist start believing in these phenomena.

Then the next step: Who is brave enough to publish this, to make it public. If you have scientists who are sincere enough to themselves, they may not be sincere to the world because they fear of their reputation. Publishing something like that is a huge risk because people might start thinking they're lunatics. And who could blame them? People can be enormously defensive and judgemental to people who threaten their beliefs.

Let's say the scientists actually decide to publish the research. First, there are not so many mediums (websites or magazines) who would want to publish such a research. The ones that do, how many people are going to read it? That is the first question. Second question: Who will take it seriously? People are inclined not to believe it, so they problably won't.  Especially if they have not had any personal experience with such phenomena.

This is just an example of how people filter what information is being accepted. I have heard about studies where something like this happened.The basic thing is this: If information goes against one's beliefs, it is rejected, ignored. If it goes in favor of, it is being embraced and used.

Second thing: Do you think we have no soul? Do you think everything that we do, think and desire are just biological processes? 

It would seem logical at first, according to logic to think that. I can understand. But if everything is simply biology, then you would have no choice in any matter whatsoever, you would deny the notion of free will. Is it not? It is a confusing matter to me too, but according to logic, if everything is simply biology, everything that you do happens in spite of you. In fact, you think there is no 'you', except your biologic, physical 'you'. But you could not choose anything. So to say that something happens in spite of you is even wrong, you could say: 'something happens'. 

Yet we all say it in words: "I can't do this to my body", "I can't live with myself any longer", "A part of me wants this, another part does not want it", "I am hurting myself". 
The most significant one of these I find this one, Eckhart Tolle had a transformation through it: "I can't live with myself any longer". He asked: "Who is this self I can not live with?" To say something like that instanly implies a duality. There is something, the 'I', and the 'self' that cannot be lived with. How can you say it is all of the same thing? It's a really deep matter and I don't compeltely grasp it myself either, but do you feel like it's possible that the "I" and the "self" are the same thing when everything is just one thing? I can not imagine it, can you?

You notice, you are aware. You are aware of what you are doing right now, you are aware of what you are seeing right now. Sometimes not fully, sometimes partially aware, but you are aware of it. If you hold out your hand in front of you, you feel it, you see it. But if you are simply a biological organism, how can you be aware of it? Then what I write here would be unconcious commands. The you would look at your hand, but not see it, not be aware that there is something that can be seen. Then you could try feel it, but you would not feel it because you would be like a command of a computer. Pain would be an instinctive reaction, but you would never suffer from it, because you could not be aware that it's even there, everything would be automatic responses. Just think about it!

Could there be loopholes in my logic? Possibly. Because I am just an ordinary human being. But it is something to really consider and really think about. 

To finish off let me leave you with this. You can have thousands of arguments in favour of, and thousands of arguments against god, or anything for that matter, but you would not be sure. You could have dedicated your whole life to prove something, you may have collected thousands of pieces of 'evidence' (if that even exists at all), but you can not be sure. There is always some kind of counter-argument that can be made, something to dismantle it. You can say that if you look at your hand, that "this is my hand and it's right here", but you do not even know if your hand is an illusion. Your hand may only appear to be there, but in reality other people don't see your hand. You may ask other people if they see your hand, they may reply with "yes", but they can be lying. You can not be sure. I'm starting to think the only thing that I can know for sure is that 'I am aware'. 

So I can not say that I believe that god exists. I honestly don't know. Based on what I've experienced and realized I am inclined to belief that he exists, but I can not be sure. I can not be sure of anything I have typed in this comment. "Why say anything at all with a sense of certainty if you´re not sure abou anything?" You may ask. It's because it's an expression of myself. Yes, strictly speaking I do not know anything, but I do not only function out of pure logic, remember that. I aim to inspire and break through some conditioned beliefs, I don't aim to not make any mistakes anywhere.

Just remember this last thing: You can have all the evidence against or in favor of god, but you do not and can not know for sure. You have to admit that you are not sure. If you're really honest with yourself, you can not do otherwise.

I wonder about consciousness. We're a bundle of different sensations and motivations and feelings. We want to do something, but sometimes we can't. Why not? Different parts of our psyche fight with other parts. We get drunk and part of one voice stops working, stops telling us no. We can have some other chemical and all of a sudden we can do the things we wanted to before, but couldn't for some reason. We can be depressed, or manic. But whatever the case, we don't have complete agency over our entire body. Try to fight against anesthesia, you can't. But yet, our respiratory and circulatory system can keep working.

So what are we? We are a collection. We're each a bunch of pieces that work together. Each of these pieces communicates with each other really rapidly. Biochemically we send hormones to and fro, electrical potentials, and pulses across neurons. Each cell theoretically possible to live on its own, if you just happened to provide it with the right environment.

So then what are we? I think about the Ship of Theseus. No single part of us is necessary. We could take out pretty much any single cell from our body, and our consciousness wouldn't follow that cell. If a doctor with incredibly precise tools were to remove one single neuron we would be fine. If you could replace it with an artificial one in the same configuration, we would be fine. If you were to swap it with a similar one from another person it would be fine. The individual cell isn't really important, it has a few jobs, and either it does them well, or it doesn't and other ones pick up the slack. But for us, no single cell defines us.

But then where do we end? If we are the manifestation of the many billions of pieces of our body working together in concert, what defines the edge of us? Is our identity in our DNA? People are born with chimaerism, and can have different genetic makeups that put together a single body. They don't feel any different themselves. They just have one body as far as they're concerned. Similarly, identical twins feel their identity is as disparate as anyone else, sure, they might be closer, or identify more closely, or whatever else. But you'd be hard pressed to find a set of twins that would argue that they should both go to jail for the crime of either of them.

So what's the difference? Is it just that when our cells communicate with eachother, they do it simply and quickly? When we communicate with other people, we have very complex ideas that we communicate slowly and imprecisely. But then isn't that just a question of scale? I mean, in astronomical terms, any communication we do with eachother is pretty much instantaneous. So is our lifespan for that matter.

So if you look at it from a different scale, are we not each analogous to the individual cells that make up a single body? One cell doesn't really recognize the presence of the whole body. It can't. It doesn't have the inputs, it doesn't think. Cells get specific feedback and act on that. But where people do differ from cells is that we can think. While we couldn't see an entire body, we can talk in analogies, we can imagine, we can project, we can abstract.

We already do it. When we talk about a country we might say "France did this today" or "The USA is strongly against that". We anthropomorphize. Countries aren't humans. But they do act like individual somethings. The behavior of an individual ant is pretty pathetic. Ants can get themselves stuck walking in circles because they're following behind their own scent trail. But the behavior of an entire colony can be quite interesting, and it's reproductive cycle is like an organism, but it's a collective.

So I think about what I am. I kind of know what I am as a person, but if I was a cell, what would I be? It would be important for me to do my selfish job, because I don't really know enough about my situation to second guess what feels good. As a person, I know that things like having kids, staying safe, building a legacy, those things drive me. But to add to that, if I am a part of a greater whole, then what changes? Not much really, except I want to respect others more. Everyone else is part of the same thing as me. It's more than just a team, it's more like we're all one organism. If I have the choice to help or hinder, I'll choose to help. If someone makes a mistake, I'll choose to forgive. There's no reason for me to try to make others feel bad, because from some way of looking at it, they're a part of me too, and it's not particularly healthy to make myself feel bad.

And then there's that thing about permanence. It makes it easy. I know that I'm not permanent. I know I'll die one day. That will be that, and there's nothing more about it. But that's fine, it's the way it's supposed to be. When skin cells die off in my body, that's a necessary part of my body's proper operation. When they're alive, they really need to do the things that they do. They are built in such a way that the normal operation and the normal environment leaves them doing exactly what they're supposed to. Their 'urges' so to speak keep them doing exactly what they're meant to. And if something gets broken, say they end up reproducing without end and not dying, then it's called cancer and it can kill a person.

But I guess the thing is, a skin cell doesn't want to reproduce malignantly. A skin cell doesn't want to do anything. We are much more complex, we want a lot more, and we do a lot more. We think a lot more, and we plan, and we act very differently. The kind of organism we make up can't be anthropomorphized. It's more than a person, and it's even more than all the people. Is this organism alone? Is it young or old? What are its goals?

Sometimes I think we're like the blastocyst. Just emerging from our spherical ovum. Just barely getting ready to break the shell.

But I don't worry about me, at least not more than I need to. I'm not going to be judged. But I do think I'm a part of something that will outlive myself. Like any cell of my own body, I'm not indispensable, but at the same time, without any cells, our bodies wouldn't exist. I'm a part of it. So who am I? Am I just the cell? Am I just the neuron that is firing to send the signal to the finger to make it press and type the letter? None of that would be possible without the cooperation of many. So as far as that is concerned, they're all me. In the same vein, this individual is one of those parts that might be considered "all me" by something larger.

If I did have a problem with an organ, or a malignant tumor, I would see it as a problem with me. I might correct it or excise it, but I wouldn't judge it. I wouldn't torment it in the pits of hell for all eternity. Why would I pass judgment on a malfunctioning part of my body? That's stupid. Nor would I expect it to predict what I wanted it to do. I would expect it to simply act like it has always acted. And I might do things that hurt me. I might end up burning myself. Parts of me will die, blister, scar. They all work in pretty predictable ways developed over a long period of evolution to close up and heal that wound. But that's unfortunate. It doesn't mean I would intentionally burn parts of my body just because I thought they were wicked.

I feel like part of something bigger, but that something bigger isn't something that we could really think of as a person, or as a master even. Just kind of a manifestation. I'm not important. I'm not driving the boat, but then again, nobody and everybody is. But it's a good thing I'm not driving because I have no idea where we are, or where we're supposed to be going, and neither does anyone else on here. But for all I know, the boat itself might be going somewhere that I can't see.

Birds fly south in the winter, but I doubt that any individual cell in their body could explain to you why.

Regardless, I do know what feels to me to be the right thing to do, and the right way to act, and the right way to treat people. And so I'm going to do that. But I'm going to respect everyone else a bit more like myself than I might if I thought that I just had to pass some tests and live in eternal luxury.

Derek, I appreciate your sincerity, but I believe you've come to a faulty conclusion.

I don't want to be argumentative, but I'm concerned that you may be making a mistake and on such a weighty matter!

I don't want to prove myself right or prove you wrong, but get to the truth. If what I think is true, then the truth will set you free from the nothingness you're concerned about.

Plus, in the spirit of "veritasium", a kind of "place for the truth," I think pursuing that truth is valuable.

I agree that the decay of the natural world (universe), including rocks and our bodies, produces feelings of futility (meaninglessness) through impermanence (death).

However, as you said said in the video, you are operating on the assumption/assertion that there cannot be a soul or a spirit. You call it a "delusion." I could guess why you might think that, but I don't want to put words in your mouth. Could I ask why?

Making meaning daily with each other is all good and fine, as far as it goes (connecting with people and loving them is so very important, of course!), but it seems to me that it becomes just meaningless if it all comes to an end like everything else. It seems to me that you end up with the same problem.

Whether you fear death or look forward to nothingness or an afterlife, you still have to grapple with what the end truly is. So your decision to "seize the day" hinges on your assumption that there is no eternal soul. Again, how are you certain that there is no soul?

I'd posit that your observations make more sense given a worldview where people do have a soul.

To back up my own assumption / worldview:
My own assumption that we have a soul stems from my belief that there is God. I believe there is a God for many reasons: faith & revelation, yes, but more relate-able than that, because I can't escape the fact that we are inherently "moral" beings. We make judgments of "this is good" and "that is bad" all the time and expect them to be universally/absolutely obeyed and observed. This only makes sense if there is a law-giver, that wrote such a moral law on "hearts". I also think it makes more sense that the natural world requires a first cause outside of nature (God) rather than a self-existing nature, especially when you consider the linearity of our universe from big-bang to heat-death.

In my worldview (and many other worldviews, for that matter), we would consider the soul to be the eternal part of the person (that exists outside of nature) while the body is the temporal / mortal part (that exists inside of nature, like rocks do). Lumping people's souls/spirit/essence in with rocks, as you have, is a categorical error for our worldview. That is: Rocks are not more permanent than people, People are more permanent than rocks.

I agree that some people live under a delusion that they will live forever and deliberately put the idea out of their mind that our bodies are mortal (we all eventually die), but I think the reason people do so is that we inherently desire to live indefinitely (have eternal life). You said as much yourself too!

You mentioned that our biology has woven into it the mechanisms to reproduce and cannot even imagine itself outside of existence.

So, according to your own observations...
1) We desire to live eternally.
i.e. we put off the idea of death indefinitely, always looking for a new tomorrow.

2) We all struggle against the fact that we are mortal.
"The sense of our morality should strike fear into us."

Your observations of our desire to live forever and your nihilist admission that "it might drive you crazy to be confronted with the meaningless of everything all the time" sounds a lot to me like what Solomon said in the book of Ecclesiastes:

"He has made everything beautiful in its time. Also, he has put eternity into man’s heart, yet so that he cannot find out what God has done from the beginning to the end." -Ecclesiastes 3:11

"I, the Teacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem. I applied my mind to study and to explore by wisdom all that is done under the heavens. What a heavy burden God has laid on mankind! I have seen all the things that are done under the sun; all of them are meaningless, a chasing after the wind."

"...So I hated life, because the work that is done under the sun was grievous to me. All of it is meaningless, a chasing after the wind. I hated all the things I had toiled for under the sun, because I must leave them to the one who comes after me. ... This too is meaningless and a great misfortune. What do people get for all the toil and anxious striving with which they labor under the sun? All their days their work is grief and pain; even at night their minds do not rest. This too is meaningless."

He comes to a similar point several times that you concluded with:
"A person can do nothing better than to eat and drink and find satisfaction in their own toil. This too, I see, is from the hand of God, for without him, who can eat or find enjoyment?"

But his final conclusion is this (notice who gives the wise words -- the one shepherd):
"The words of the wise are like goads, their collected sayings like firmly embedded nails—given by one shepherd. Be warned, my son, of anything in addition to them.
Of making many books there is no end, and much study wearies the body.
Now all has been heard;

Fear God and keep his commandments,

Existential Nihilism ftw

TRANSCRIPTION:

I'm not sure what I expected to find when I went to Chernobyl when it's been so long since the nuclear reactor there melted down and spewed radioactive atoms across the land. So for almost thirty years,
this place has been virtually abandoned. These days, workers are allowed into the zone, but only for two weeks at a time. And that's not because the radiation levels are too high, it's actually for psychological reasons. More than two weeks in a place like this will apparently make you think strange things. And I was only here for four days, but I started to think about rocks. Yeah, rocks.\\
Rocks appear to be permanent. I mean I know that they aren't. Mountains are constantly eroding and in places the crust is melting back into the mantle. Rock obviously isn't permanent, but on the scale of a human life it is.
And people have recognized that fact. Rocks are permanent for thousands of years and I think that's what makes them important to us. I mean, a diamond is forever. We build these monuments out of rocks because they will outlast us and virtually every other material we can think of. Our modern structures of metal and glass are just rock refined by our ingenuity. Rocks are both pratical and symbolic. We seek to identify ourselves with rocks. We carve our heroes in stone because we want them to last forever. In there's a way in which we want that kind of permanence for ourselves to.\\
I think it's at the core of the desire to scratch our name into stone or
put your initials intwet cement, really made man rock, or fasten a padlock to a bridge. In this way, we try to push our impermanence from our minds. The monuments, statues, bridges, they give us a sense of continuity, stability, that this is the way it is and the way it's always been, like the way we first conceived of stars, static, unchanging, eternal. And this way of viewing the world helps us maintain our greatest delusion, the thought that we are in any way eternal.\\
We wanna believe that some part of us, our consciousness or our soul, will last forever. But what do you make of it then when you see stone is not even so permanent. Walking around Chernobyl I think it's understandable that I started contemplating not only the permanence of rocks but also their decay and by extension our decay, death, what the world would look like without people.
You know the closest I can come to imagining true nothingness is to picture the universe running really fast in reverse. All the galaxies squeezing closer together, stars expanding back into gas clouds and everything getting hotter and denser, compactifying until the whole observable universe could fit into a room and then shrinking further into a tiny point and then, nothing. Not the nothingness of empty space, but, real nothingness, which has no size, and no time.
To me, that is probably what death looks like. A nothingness so complete you wouldn't even miss it. For that, you'd have to be there. But just as soon as I can form this thought, it evaporates, like a void in nature, the world rushes in to fill it. And this makes sense, because the hardware I'm running has been developed over billions of years with the only requirement being that it frequently and accurately makes copies of itself. And it would help not in the slightest in the goal of making copies if the hardware could accurately simulate its own non-existance. When we do acknowledge our impermanence, it is often through incipid catchphrases like "YOLO", or it's in art projects like Damian Herst's "the physicsl impossilbity of death in the mind of someone living", which is just a huge shark in a tank of formaldehyde. A sense of our mortality should strike fear into us, like the sense I have when I'm swimming hundreds of meters offshore and the water below is deep and dark and I can picture the shark swimming beneath me. The same kind of fate stalks us daily but not in this visceral way, just in a trivial, ignorable way, hence the delusion. You're permanent, like stone, always were, always will be. So, we are left hard-wired for denial, the selected inability to imagine true nothingness in a sack of particles that thinks itself eternal. This delusion is comforting and it makes living easier, might drive you crazy to be confronted with the ultimate meaninglessness of everything all the time, what called nihilism. But the same delusion I argue is also debilitating. It lulls you into a false sense of security, inaction, like a due date a long time in the future. There's always tomorrow, so we procrastinate living the life we truly desire. And we live in more fear. The sense that your soul is eternal makes you cowardly, because failure would stick with you forever, for really ever.
Shame, embarassment, disappointment, they would never leave you. A distant horizon encourages you to play it safe, live to fight another day, for after all, there's is always another day. And this is why I find nihilism liberating and emboldening. If you can really picture the nothingness that awaits you, then what is there to be afraid of. Errors and humiliations will be forgotten, but great achievements may not. We may have no meaning in the cosmic context of the universe, but we make our own meaning daily with each other. And this is the thought that leads to action. Your days are numbered, you don't know what that number is, but it's finite, so get busy with what it is that you want to do. Time is running out.

Also there are lots of people discussing science and truth, how valid they are, how subjective/objective they are. To clear this up, there is are really two kinds of truth, things that are true by definition (like math) called A Priori truths, and things that are true because they have been proven through evidence from the outside world called A Posteriori truths. The problem is that you need A Posteriori evidence to prove your A Posteriori truths, so they are inherently unreliable. This problem is often referred to a the Brain in a Vat scenario, and is demonstrated well in the Matrix. The assumptions that you use to resolve the chicken and egg predicament of evidence and truth will change your interpretation of the "truth" that you arrive at. Some people believe that there is an objective Truth to A Posteriori truths, but this is an assumption and impossible to prove or disprove. I personally prefer of nice mixing of Transcendental Idealism with Existentialism, and relativism. The universe is definite, but arbitrary and unreachable, meaning that our source of purpose is ourselves and others rather than existence itself.

I've long contemplated these ideas... the first time I tried to visualize "nothingness" I realized it would be most-similar to looking behind your head, not black, not white, not even "empty", but just simply "nothing"... you don't see darkness outside your field of vision, you have no perception of space, or therefore emptiness.

I've also realized while doing Genealogy that my reasons were the same as the Pharaohs of Egypt for building the Pyramids, Michelangelo for carving "David", Leonardo for painting "Mona Lisa".... to create something from yourself, a part of you, your creation, which can outlast you, and thus gain some degree of immortality.

There's an old idea which goes back to the days of ancient Egypt, but Banksy said it really succinctly ""They say you die twice. Once when you stop breathing and the second, a bit later on, when somebody mentions your name for the last time."

The Pharaohs of ancient Egypt may be dead, but they live on in stories, movies, songs, etc, even in the modern day... They have achieved what is otherwise impossible, some degree of immortality.

And it's worthy to note that many, if not most of us, do this by having children of our own.  Our children bear with them in their lives a combination of both our genetic material, what makes us "us"... but also our own ideas... We teach our children what we want them to know and understand, we tell them stories about our lives both so that they may learn from them, but also learn about us.  In doing so, we're also passing on our live stories onto them, hoping that they may someday tell their children something about us, perhaps even stories we told them of their grandparents and great-grandparents.

As I get older the desire to leave a lasting mark on this world becomes almost palpable... at times it can really feel like a clock is ticking, there's only so many opportunities to leave some mark that won't be washed away so quickly by the sands of time.

Speaking scientifically, energy can not be created or destroyed. Regardless of whether our nature as humans is eternal or impermanent is irrelevant. It is blatantly anti-scientific to say that there are not some aspects of our universe that are eternal. The fact is that life is a fruition of the endless nature of that energy and systems of converting that energy from one form into another, this is scientifically undisputed. It can be said that a life form is more or less a system of energy conversions, one part of that system converts chemical energy to electrical energy, electric energy into mechanical energy so that an other part of that system can convert it back again. However, to say we completely understand the connection between energy and consciousness is also very unscientific. In our lifetime we will never fully know the connection between the energy that we know is within all things and its influence over consciousness. We have a general understanding of how the brain works mechanically but we have no idea how energy applied to a system like the brain, can cause consciousness or the ability to observe, or even why it observes anything at all.

Rocks. Rocks appear to be permanent. I mean I know that they aren't. Mountains are constantly eroding
and in places the crust is melting back into the mantle. Rock obviously isn't permanent but on the scale of human life, it is and people recognized that fact. Rocks are permanent for thousands of years and I think that's what makes them important to us. I mean, "a diamond is forever", we build these monuments to outlast us and our modern structure of metal and glass are just rock refined by our ingenuity. We seek to indentify ourselves with rocks. We carve our heroes in stone because we want them to last forever and there's a way in which we want that kind of permanence in ourselves too. I think it's in the core of the desire to scratch our name into stone, put initials in wet cement or fasten a padlock to a bridge. In this way, we try to push our impermanence from our minds. The monuments, the statues and bridges, they give us a sense of continuity. Stability. That this is the way it is and the way it's always been. Like the first we concieved of stars: static, unchanging, internal. And this way of viewing the world helps us maintain our greatest delusion. The thought tat we are in any way eternal. We want to believe that some part of us, our consciousness or our soul will last forever. But what do you make of it when stone isn't even permanent? The closest I can ccome to imagining true nothingness is to picture the universe running really fast in reverse. All the galaxies squeezing closer together, stars expanding back into gas clouds and everything getting hotter and denser, compactifying until the whole observable universe could fit into a room and then sinking further into a tiny point and then; nothing. Not the nothingness of empty space but real nothingess which has no size and no time. To me that is probably what death looks like. Nothiness so complete you wouldn't even miss it. For that, you have to be there. But just as soon as I can form this thought, it evaporates like a void in nature. The world rushes in to fill it and this make sense because the hardware I'm running has been developed over billions of years with the only requriement being that it frequently inaccurately makes copies of itself and would help not inthe slightest in the goal of making copies  if the hardware could accurately simulate its own non-existence. When we do acknowledge our impermanence, it is through insipid catch phrases like "yolo" or it's in art projects like Damien Hirst's "The physical impossibility of death in the mind of someone living". Our sense of our mortality should strike fear into us. The fate of dying stalks us daily but not in this visceral way just in trivial ignorable way. Hence the delusion. You're permanent like stone. Always and always will be. So we are left hardwired for denial and selected inability to imagine true nothingness. An ephemeral sack sack of particles that thinks itself eternal.  This delusion is comforting and it makes living easier. It might drive you crazy to be confronted bwith the ultimate meaninglessness of everything all the time, of what we call nihilism. But the same delusion I'd argue is also debilitating. Hope and acceptance are crucial elements of human life, and that's one of the reasons humans are a contradictive species.

The description of the Big Bang contains a common misconception. The singularity should not be depicted as being surrounded by nothing/darkness nor should it really be thought of as a point. Yes, each point in space had infinite density at the Big Bang but the singularity is more about our understanding of physics breaking down and thus the density going to infinity. It's not a point in the normal sense. If you rewind time as you showed with the animation then galaxies get closer, stars turn to gas of increasing temperature and density, and space shrinks. However, since space is infinite the singularity that contains our observable universe came from would be next to another equally dense point that leads to another region outside our current observable universe. I guess my main gripe, and it's a minor one, is that Big Bang animations should not show a point of light exploding into blackness but rather start with the whole screen lit up and then as the screen dims structures become visible coalescing and expanding away from each other.

Don't worry about running counter to the idea of meaninglessness because it's not possible. Nihilism is a word which was originally coined to denote the objective non-existence of moral values in the universe - it is the conceptual product of a philosophical analysis derived from an atheistic perspective. What is annihilated is always an illusion. And it is not meaning which is annihilated (since that is paradoxical) but, rather, value. So a nihilist might say that life has plenty of meaning, but utterly lacks purpose - and therefore value.

Nihilism is not a style of thinking that one can achieve or perform. It is an anti-doctrine. It is an anti-aesthetic. I think, in recent times, it has been used far more frequently than in times past, and this has both enlarged and diluted its meaning.

My main issue is when you say that to have a view if eternity means to bear all of your mistakes and shame with you forever. But that really depends on which worldview you are talking about. Not all world views have opinions like that, even if yours does. To make a grand blanket statement like that is to do a great disservice to the other world views out there that view eternity in a different light, and it's not very academic to simply brush them away without explanation or consideration. Some view eternity as a celebration that their shame and mistakes did not overcome them.

You also say that an eternal world view lures people into the trap of inactivity. Although, while that may be partially true, it's again a blanket statement. Take the christian world view, they view that eternity is a new journey/exploration of discovery and celebration with their creator, provided they come to know him before death. Most christians find the thought of people being separated from their creator for eternity unbearable, and that spurs them into immense action, travelling to people groups across the world to aid people and spread their news. Whether or not you agree with their world view is irrelevant for your argument, I'm just pointing out it violates the blanket statement you made, and why blanket statements are never helpful or informative.

Also, as others have mentioned, to say you find meaning in nihilism is a contradiction. According to nihilism, the "meaning" you find in nihilism is a lie that you tell to yourself just to keep yourself going through life, as there is no true meaning, not even the meaning that you make for yourself. Therefore, you are contributing to the great delusion yourself. Deluding yourself into thinking you can craft your own meaning. And that meaning that you do make for yourself is honestly simly limited by income, status, where you live, affluence, etc. So you're not really free to do what you want at all. 

I guess I just think that it's a little irresponsible to settle on a world view before you've taken the time to study, dissect, and analyze all major world views. It's one of life's decisions that has the largest and most far-reaching implications, yet people make blanket statements, jump to conclusions, and don't study and test their options. They just jump into whichever is most convenient for them, regardless if it holds up consistently across all tests. I believe in all areas of life, one should be academic and make informed decisions, including death and eternity.

Permanence means lack of change, lack of change is the antithesis of life. 

Humans, indeed all remotely sentient life, possibly ALL life, seeks continuance.  Is this a mere result of chemical processes that have evolved to ensure organisms live long enough to procreate?

We Know evolution is not a sentient being making choices, rather, evolution is a consequence of DNA, which is a consequence of chemistry, physics etc all the way down to the beginning of our universe (if there truly was one). 

My head is full of fancy ideas about how our consciousness in some form continues on beyond the death of the body.  Even if only in the loosest sense of the concept. 

Sagan's point about the human mind is the universe contemplating itself is IMHO one of the few spiritual sounding things a scientist/atheist can really say with conviction.  

Monists in various forms have said for some time that we, indeed ALL of the universe is one thing, with separation being an illusion.  Duality is a tool the universal mind created within the observer/s and is little more than an illusion. 

Humans are complex pattern recognition machines, even where there is no pattern we invent it.  We create order out of chaos, indeed, even our concept or chaos is quite orderly.  Without humans, or beings like us and the other remotely aware beings on this planet, or elsewhere in the universe what would the universe be but a collection of energy dispersed throughout the universe which has no form or substance, no order or even disorder.  

Without an observer to say that a star is a star and empty space is empty, the stuff that makes the star and the empty space is no less real, but it's significance as two separate things, it's duality, vanishes instantly. 

Humans can be thought of as a sand dune... 

Some dunes travel across deserts, taking many years.  every moment that dune exists it is different from the moment before.  Sand particles are blown away or left behind as it drifts, and new sand takes it's place.  Yet we humans still consider it the same dune, even though nothing about it remains the same.

The same is true for almost all "permanent" or even temporary things.  Like ourselves.

Life, like other forms of energy, Propagates through matter, shaping it into a self replicating self sustaining form for as long as possible. 

Most if not all of our atoms are replaced over 15 years, those few that don't get swapped out much if at all - are they US?  For example, the atoms in the enamel of your tooth, they don't really swap out, does that mean we are our teeth?

Of course not.  We are not the physical atoms, not the temporary ones, nor the permanent. 

Are we (the aware part of us) then just the emergent phenomenon of the Wave of our life energy moving through time and matter?  Is awareness an elementary property of life?

There does not appear to be any intelligence guiding evolution, or our path through the universe beyond what we individually believe we choose, but an ameba, or bacteria... are they aware?  Or are they simple machines that react to stimulus and have no awareness?  If we are made up of organisms no different than those bacteria in terms of awareness... where does our awareness come from?

Where is it?  Where does it go when the body shuts down, even temporarily?

Are we no more than a biological program loaded into the RAM of a biological machine, memory which is flushed when the RAM chips are switched off?

How come we can indeed, switch off for a short period (near death etc) and all brain function stop, then be restarted (sometimes) and how come we can come back?

Is our awareness stored on a biological hard drive? How come it doesn't have any locality within the body?  Sure if we destroy the brain the awareness goes with it, but we can show that no one part of the brain clearly holds awareness, we can get close sometimes, but it always appears to peak out from some other place when we look for it. 

A lot of what I'm saying is conjecture, and borders on "God of the Gaps." reasoning, except, I am not postulating very much, I am not declaring things to be true as inferred from the things I don't know.   

However, I am simply trying to ask the right questions with the right logical/factual foundation.   There are a lot of places I and we together can go on this subject. 

My gut says that the answer is something very obvious, but utterly not what we think it is... that is, it's probably not God, it's probably not oblivion as Derek seams to suggest, but it's also not permanent or eternal either... Perhaps, like the fundamental laws themselves, this question will never be answered... why is light light, why is kinetic energy kinetic... Why is life life... and death death... 

I do however firmly believe (even if unscientifically) that life is energy... Energy cannot be created nor destroyed, only changed in form. That doesn't mean we have a soul, but it can mean we can at least trust that like our atoms, our life energy will propagate into the universe and perhaps be part of new life somewhere someday.

My thoughts deviate a bit from @Veritasium though, as i do not believe people today are living like robots. Nor do i believe nihilism is anything but debilitating. Sure, there is less to fear, but what would one fear without nihilism? Ending up in hell? Reincarnating into an insect?

As with our personal behaviour, i have noticed more that people without religion tend, as mentioned, to persue their own self-interest a lot more. However, this self-interest seems in many cases to be self-destructive. I live in norway, and there are few people here who believe in any gods, and if they do, they do not tend to follow the rules of the religion, but instead use it as a cultural meeting of sorts. That has meant that, at least from my perspective, that people are devoting their life to frivolities - drinking, videogames, entertainment, obsession of self-image, etc. To me, even from a nihilist point of view, that is worth objectivly less than the actions of a society with a non-nihilist point of view. None of these people strive to do anything great. They will make money, entertain themselves, and live the end of their days in much the same way as they did the first ones - with as much food and entertainment as they would like. 

I disagree with this static reality, and i have some gut-feeling that i need to do more. I need to have an impact on history. I want to, as the video mentions, be remembered. That is not a preoccupation, that is purpose. Therefore, i devote my life to do anything in my power to attain that purpose. Using admittantly metaphysical reasoning, i have found that my chance of greatness increases if i try to live my life as the ancient philosophers and religious figures wrote one should - working on self-discipline,self-improvement, spiritual and mental excercise, and trying to achieve a prime - being a stoic.
